p: On the other hand, the allocation of large amounts of energy to carbohydrate storage in the roots seem to come at the cost of decreased growth. It suggests that the carbohydrates stored in the roots cannot be converted into photosynthetic tissue, and therefore incur a loss in growth rate. Invasive J. vulgaris genotypes, which allocate less to carbohydrate storage, showed significantly more biomass accumulation than native genotypes (TableÂ 1). It suggests that regrowth is a costly strategy.
